message:
In the words of Mr.Kennedy, “Children are the world's most valuable resource and its best hope for the future”.
Keeping this spirit in mind, here is our second video on our Student Speak blog by Gopali Youth Welfare Society on the various initiatives they have undertaken to help realise this potential.

Link to Blog: http://www.barc.iitkgp.ac.in/blog/index.php/2018/08/29/children-are-the-worlds-most-valuable-resource-and-its-best-hope-for-future-gopali-youth-welfare-society/

If you also have any stories to tell about your life here, we invite you to share them with us. We will release them through our Blog and Facebook page. You will get the benefit of getting your story heard not only inside the institution but on the national level.
You can share your stories with us at: https://docs.google.com/…/1FAIpQLSe8BD2DjKDSSkbY87…/viewform

Bioelectronics: a relatively unexplored field in the country, yet exciting nonetheless found a face in IIT Khargpur as the institute set up India’s pioneering Bioelectronics Innovation Laboratory to develop futuristic battery free implantable medical devices. With the help of coin sized chips with wireless energy supply, the Laboratory aims to solve problems that are otherwise unaddressed by latest medical sciences. Headed by Prof Sudip Nag from Electronics and Electrical Department, IIT Kharagpur, and aided by grants from MHRD and other avenues  this initiative aims to offer cost effective reliable solutions for the common population. Setting up collaborations with various hospitals and incubating companies for marketing and development are the few formalities that need to be completed before these new innovative medical devices start working for the welfare of the public.

https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/iit-kharagpur-sets-up-bioelectronics-innovation-laboratory/articleshow/65237645.cms

In a huge country like India, a report reveals that every minute  the country is facing a serious road accident and every four minutes a person dies in a road accident. A recent study made by IIT Kharagpur’s Civil Engg. Department, under the ‘Safe drive save life’ campaign by the state public works department of West Bengal, made a host of recommendations on speed regulation. High speed national highways, NH-60 and NH-117 were  chosen for the  study as they account for a majority of accidents and fatal crashes. The results of the study, conducted under the able guidance of Professor Sudeshna Mitra, emphasised on speed zoning and  greater technical consultation at the planning stage to ensure proper speed control. Owing to the ‘Safe drive save life’ campaign, accident figures have come down in West Bengal and this study will only help in lowering them further.

Technology Transfer Group , IIT Kharagpur organized the 2nd INAE Youth Conclave in IIT Kharagpur. The event witnessed a footfall of over 200 enthusiastic participants, where they presented their solutions to 6 problem statements spanning across 3 genres. A total prize money of 10 lakhs was given away to the winners of each category. After having seen immense participation and incredible work in the 2nd INAE Youth Pre Conclave held in March where teams were shortlisted to show their work in the Conclave, the Conclave became much more exciting. The Conclave was graced by the presence of Honourable guests such as the Chairman of AICTE, Prof. Anil Sahasrabuddhe, the President of INAE, Dr. B.N. Suresh, the Vice-President of INAE, Prof. Purnendu Ghosh, the Director of IIT Delhi Prof. V. Ramgopal Rao and the Director of IIT Kharagpur, Prof. Partha Pratim Chakrabarti.
To know what Anil Sahasrabudhe, All India Council for Technical Education Chairman had spoken to encourage innovation, kindly go through the following link. 
https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/aicte-chairman-stresses-on-new-initiatives-to-encourage-118081301244_1.html

IIT Kharagpur has secured the Chairman Award for Technical Innovation in India Innovation Challenge Design Contest (IICDC) 2017. The award was given on Battery Health Management System with Integrated Charger by Texas Instruments India(TI). More than 15,380 students of 965 colleges took part with 30 teams have made it to the final after a rigorous selection process. The winners qualify for an Rs. 3.5 crore start-up seed fund from the Department of Science and Technology (DST) and an opportunity to be incubated at IIM Bangalore's innovation and entrepreneurship hub N S Raghavan Centre for Entrepreneurial Learning (NSRCEL).

IIT Kharagpur won their first-ever medal in the State Athletics Championship, at the Salt Lake Stadium on Saturday. In what was just their second appearance in the state meet, IIT Kharagpur bagged bronze in men's 4x100m relay, clocking 44.4 seconds behind Police AC and East Bengal, on the penultimate day of the competition.

Eslavath Jaga Deesh , Shivam singh , Sairam Alla and Lokesh Reddi were the ones who earned IIT Kharagpur their first-ever medal in the state meet. Coach Mr. Pranab Sarkar said: "I would only say that our performance is getting better. The bronze medal is a testimony of it.

The team will be taking part in men's 100 metres, 400m hurdles and 4x400m relay, and the coach is confident of more medals coming in on the final day.

message:
IIT Kharagpur Empowers New Joinees through Induction Program

IIT Kharagpur is conducting a week-long Induction program for first year students. During this period, students are participating in a wide range of social activities, sports challenges, and life skills programs. Through this induction program the Institute aims to inform the new joinees about academic and social issues, have better understanding of the academic environment,awareness regarding various informative services, familiarity with the campus life etc. “The students come with a lot of talent, however, after intensive preparation for the entrance and for smooth transition from home environment to that of IIT atmosphere, they need guidance. We will help the students generate interest in their respective areas of study and recognize skills they would require to do well. It is critical they develop a sense of belongingness to the Institute and friendship with their peers and seniors thus adapting to the transition” said Prof. Somesh Kumar, Dean, Students’ Affairs. The students are starting their day at morning 6.00 AM with sessions in Yoga and games followed by programs to explore their areas of creative and cultural interests, and activities in life skills. Prof. Priyadarshi Patnaik who is heading this initiative is hopeful that the Induction program would help students build interpersonal relations through direct interactions instead of social media communication. “It will also help them with greater insight about themselves and others around them which will in turn help them deal with stress, conflicts, competitions, create a stronger bonding with the student and faculty community” he remarked. The students will get the opportunity to interact with the Director, administrative team, faculty members and senior students of IIT Kharagpur to learn about the Institute and community life,their halls of residence and respective departments and opportunities thereof. Motivational sessions by alumni achievers have also been organized related to career, success, culture,frontiers of science and technology, self, etc. “This Induction Program has proved to be extremely helpful to us. We would otherwise have gone to various sections of the Institute and spent much longer period of time to collect this information which is critical for us” said Balashree, a first year student.

Through this induction program the Institute aims to inform the new joinees about academic and social issues, have better understanding of the academic environment,awareness regarding various informative services, familiarity with the campus life etc. “The students come with a lot of talent, however, after intensive preparation for the entrance and for smooth transition from home environment to that of IIT atmosphere, they need guidance. We will help the students generate interest in their respective areas of study and recognize skills they would require to do well. It is critical they develop a sense of belongingness to the Institute and friendship with their peers and seniors thus adapting to the transition” said Prof. Somesh Kumar, Dean, Students’ Affairs. The students are starting their day at morning 6.00 AM with sessions in Yoga and games followed by programs to explore their areas of creative and cultural interests, and activities in life skills. Prof. Priyadarshi Patnaik who is heading this initiative is hopeful that the Induction program would help students build interpersonal relations through direct interactions instead of social media communication. “It will also help them with greater insight about themselves and others around them which will in turn help them deal with stress, conflicts, competitions, create a stronger bonding with the student and faculty community” he remarked. The students will get the opportunity to interact with the Director, administrative team, faculty members and senior students of IIT Kharagpur to learn about the Institute and community life,their halls of residence and respective departments and opportunities thereof. Motivational sessions by alumni achievers have also been organized related to career, success, culture,frontiers of science and technology, self, etc. “This Induction Program has proved to be extremely helpful to us. We would otherwise have gone to various sections of the Institute and spent much longer period of time to collect this information which is critical for us” said Balashree, a first year student.

A pacemaker runs only as long as its battery, after which the battery needs to be replaced. New research has come up with an alternative that can power the pacemaker continuously — a nanogenerator that harvests electricity out of spider silk. Scientists at IIT Kharagpur , along with a team of researchers from South Korea, have devised a self-powered, piezoelectric nanogenerator that can harvest green energy from various mechanical and biomechanical motions.

Piezoelectricity is the generation of electric charges in certain solid materials in response to applied mechanical stress — such as the body’s motion, wind and water flow, or sound vibration. A piezoelectric nanogenerator can harvest external kinetic or mechanical/bio-mechanical energy into electrical energy via action by means of a nano-structured piezoelectric material.

The research, published in Nano Energy, describes how piezoelectricity can be generated by applying pressure on fibre — in this case spider-silk fibre. IIT Kharagpur scientists say this technology can be used in healthcare monitoring, such as in pacemakers and other medical equipment.

“There are many materials in nature which have piezoelectric properties. When pressure is applied, it leads to changes in the molecular structure of the material, making it capable of harvesting mechanical/bio-mechanical energy into green electricity. When capacitors are attached to the external circuit, the electrical energy can be stored and this becomes an alternative energy source to thermal energy or hydroelectric energy or solar energy,” said Professor B B Khatua of IIT Kharagpur's Material Science Center, who led the research. “There are various ceramic or metal-oxide-based piezoelectric materials. But due to their brittleness and toxic nature, these materials have limitations for application inside the human body. Spider silk, however, is both biocompatible and biodegradable and is therefore perfect for being used inside the body.”

While the pacemaker will keep the heart ticking, the heartbeat will in turn keep the pacemaker going. “In battery-operated pacemakers, once the life of the battery is over, you need to replace it. Assembling a spider-silk-based nano generator as a self-chargeable power source, the energy required to make the pacemaker work can be created by the heartbeat. Every time the heart beats, it will create external pressure on the spider silk, making it generate energy,” Prof Khatua said.

The nanogenerator was prepared by spraying water on spider silk and wrapping it around the device. The power generated from a single unit lights up 25 green LEDs instantly. Prof Khatua said it can be used not only in pacemakers but in many other devices, and also for harvesting green energy and even for large-scale industrial applications.

“The self-powered, spider-silk-based flexible nanogenerator is extremely sensitive to even minute pressure generated from body motions, even the very small pressure arising from arterial pulse (signals arising out of small strains), throat movement during coughing, speaking, and drinking. This shows its potentiality in healthcare-monitoring applications… Its sensitiveness could also be used to monitor robotic applications,” he said.

It is the first time that a natural product like spider silk has been effectively used as a piezoelectric nanogenerator without any chemical treatment. Prof Khatua said the same team had conducted similar research with onion peels, which was published last year by IIT Kharagpur. The spider-silk energy technology took one year to devise.

Professor Khatua said devices made of these materials have the added advantage of size. “They can be thin, like a band-aid,” he said. “It can externally be used for small electronic devices such as mobile phones, watches and calculators among others.” Prof Khatua’s team included IIT research student Sumanta Kumar Karan, in collaboration with Prof Jin Kon Kim and Dr Sandip Maiti (ex-PhD student of Prof Khatua) from POSTECH, South Korea. The piezoelectric nature of the spider silk was further tested and improvised by a research team of Prof Yunseok Kim from SKKU, South Korea. IIT Kharagpur will apply for a patent and then look at commercial technology transfer.

Scientists from IIT Kharagpur have used eggshell proteins to develop tiny devices that can harvest electricity from body movements, and could power wearable sensors and devices in future.Proteins found in eggshell membranes have piezoelectric properties, that is, under mechanical stress they produce electricity. Bio-inspired piezoelectric materials are considered to be an excellent energy harvesting source, since they are non-toxic and bio-compatible. They also have the ability to generate significant power to the energy deficient world without contributing to environmental pollution. 
 Bio-piezoelectric have serious drawbacks, such as availability, toxicity, non-biodegradable, non-bio compatibility, industrially unfavorable as well as complex fabrication steps, which limit its potential applications in real life.
The membrane was coated on both sides with thin copper tapes, and gold electrodes were attached to them. The arrangement was encapsulated in silicon-based organic polymer.Researchers showed that assembling five of these devices provides enough voltage to light-up over 90 green LEDs. The findings suggest that the advance can be effectively commercialized.The device is ultra-sensitive towards very minute pressure arising from pulse, body motions at rest and walking conditions and water drop, suggesting that it could be used to power numerous applications including fitness trackers, health monitors and sensors.
The work would have a significant role towards up-lifting the green energy harvesting technology as self-powered implantable and wearable electronics.

IIT Kharagpur as it makes its way past all other institutes to be ranked as the best government institute of the country in a report by India Today. It has been made possible not only because of a single-minded focus on academic excellence and cutting-edge research in science and technology , but also because of an emphasis on fields as diverse as management, law and humanities; the institute being the first among all IITs to offer such programmes. With a broad- based flexible academic curriculum that allows a variety of courses to be pursued in tandem as well as tie-ups with several top global universities for joint academic programmes, IIT Kharagpur offers a unique learning experience that has been instrumental in producing world class graduates.

Life at IIT Kharagpur is not only about attending lectures, studying and more studying. Although it boasts of an excellent academic record, there is , in fact much more to life within the campus. There are numerous avenues whereby you can express yourself and mold the artist underneath. Ranging from debating and dramatics to dance and music, from space technology and open source to film production and finance, you are never really short of opportunities to discover yourself with Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur(TSG) being the hub of all these activities. In addition, there are excellent research groups, whose performances on the global scale are improving day by day, and if you find them interesting, you can join them too. Fun and frolic is almost always on the cards with a plethora of fests and competitions being organized throughout the semesters to keep you entertained. If you are still short on entertainment , if you still feel the need to cheer up, you can always look forward to hall days and Illumination, an indigenous way of celebrating Diwali in the campus. All in all , life at IIT Kharagpur is not just limited to studies ,but is a journey worth undertaking ; a roller coaster ride that would leave you satiated in the end.

Standing on the pillars of excellence and innovation, one of the main aims of IIT-Kharagpur is to impart quality education not just to the students inside but also to the students beyond its boundaries and over the last few years it has worked tirelessly to bridge this gap as well as to connect students, researchers, professors at all levels. For this, various initiatives, such as the NDL (National Digital Library), GIAN( Global Initiative for Academic Networks), TEQIP(Technical Education Quality Improvement Programme) , have been undertaken with an emphasis on changing the current scenario of education in the country. In addition, to foster creative thinking skills in students from a young age, IIT Kharagpur has curated special ATAL tinkering labs where schools students get a chance to express themselves and innovate. With a lot to look forward to, IIT Kharagpur is playing its part in empowering people and improving the quality of life.

Please go through Video for more details: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=CCz9XD2rpn0

At the Smart India Hackathon  grand finals at IIT Kharagpur, nine teams are working hard to build their hardware solutions as a working prototype
IIT Kharagpur is hosting the Grand Finale of the Smart India Hackathon 2018 – Hardware Edition on the theme “Agriculture/Agro-Electronics”. The Hardware Edition of SIH2018 was inaugurated through video-conferencing on June 18 by the Honorable Minister of HRD, Mr Prakash Javadekar, simultaneously at 10 nodal centers of the country. 
At IIT Kharagpur, the shortlisted nine teams from Chennai, Sambalpar, Berhampur, Pune, Coimbatore, Aurangabad, Nagpur, Palghar (Maharashtra) are slogging it off at various laboratories and centers together with their mentors who are from the Institute. The teams that come up with the best projects will be provided assistance to form start-ups compatible with industry incubators, and will have marketing support under this Central government initiative that seeks to identify new and disruptive technologies to solve real-time problems affecting the country. 
During the inauguration on June 18, Mr Prakash Javadekarr pointed out that mart India Hackathon, which is in tune with Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s “ Make In India” initiative, would help India tap into the innovative potential of its youth that the country needed to come within the top 25 nations in the world innovation index. India’s rank is currently 60 in that index. 
The teams participating in the grand finals at IIT Kharagpur have novel themes, such as water conservation in farming using Smart drip irrigation method, soil tester to help farmers decide the best cash crop to grow and what selling price to expect at the time of harvest, GSM based automatic irrigation control system using an Android mobile, development of portable E-Nose to prevent the loss of harvested fruits, solar operated multipurpose wheat harvesting machine and so on. At the end of each day, the teams are evaluated by a jury on their day’s work.
At the national-level 5,000 entries on 11 themes: smart communication, healthcare, clean water, ago-electronics, waste management, smart vehicles, technologies for rural development, education, drones and robotics, security and surveillance, and import substitution, were scrutinized by an expert evaluation committee chaired by the Director IIT Kharagpur. Over 150 short-listed teams are working at the nodal center for five days to build their hardware solutions as a working prototype.
“The Smart India Hardware Hackathon is a unique large-scale end-to-end innovation initiative that takes a student through the entire gamut - from an idea to a startup - making it possible for any college student group to display and flower their talent. This first hardware edition will be a landmark in seeding and spawning multiplicative growth in our innovation potential. I look forward to some really exciting outcomes from this,” said Prof Partha Pratim Chakrabarti, Chairman, SIH2018, and Director IIT Kharagpur.

IIT Kharagpur: The right choice

It is that time of the year. Anxious students and their doubly anxious parents are eagerly seeking counseling for admission to the star colleges in the country. Topping that list of colleges are the IIT's. Yes, even clearing JEE Advanced does not secure peace of mind for either students or their parents.

As many as 31,980 students have qualified the JEE Advanced this year. With the results just out, many know their scores, but not where they are headed or which discipline they would like to opt for. The social media is, naturally, abuzz with all sorts of queries. For those with a reasonably good score, the question is, “Should I join Electronics or Computer Science to ensure better placement?” Some have been asking, “With a score like mine, I may be eligible for Agriculture & Food Engineering. But what are the placement prospects?”

Experts at the Career Development Centre, IIT Kharagpur say that in the end, it is the CGPA that matters, and not the discipline one studies. If students acquire the right skills, both core and interdisciplinary, and maintain their CGPA, they have a good chance of getting internships and placements of their choice, no matter which department they study in. 

IIT Kharagpur offers UG students a variety of courses in its 19 main academic units. They can opt for B.Tech or Dual Degree courses in any of the academic units. What is special about  IIT Kharagpur is that the Institute allows students ‘minor’courses, microspecializations or micro credit courses through which they can gain competencies across disciplines. IIT Kharagpur also allows students ‘department change’, i.e, at the end of the first year, which features a common curriculum for all B.Tech students, about 10% students can apply for a change of major. 

A simplified procedure allows students to do their bachelor thesis project in other branches or take core courses instead. This allows students to make career choices irrespective of their qualifying degree. 

Interdisciplinary courses at IIT Kharagpur given the unique diversity of its academic units and research capability, cover a wide range of areas highly relevant to industry. ( IIT Kharagpur has 10 Centers, 12 Schools and more than 30 focused R&D units) 

Take IIT Kharagpur’s interdisciplinary Dual Degree programs. In this program, while the B.Tech is undertaken in one major discipline, M.Tech can be undertaken in another discipline ranging from analytics, computation, finance, programming, engineering entrepreneurship or quality engineering design and manufacturing. All these skills are highly valued in top multinational corporations and PSUs. 

International exposure is considered crucial by the Institute. Apart from inviting foreign faculty to take classes in the Institute through the government-funded #GIAN (Global Initiative of Academic Networks ) program, IIT Kharagpur also runs several programs of its own that facilitate the process. #The_Foreign_Training_Program (FTP) enables and financially supports students to find foreign research internships. 

#The_Semester_Away_Program (SAP) also provides students of IIT Kharagpur the unique opportunity of studying in any university of their choice whether in India or abroad for a semester. Recently, IIT Kharagpur’s Alumni have come forward to partially fund foreign internships of students. The cumulative result is that the past few years have seen a steady spike in students opting for foreign internships to train in areas of their interest, which might be management, art, architecture, innovation etc.

Apart from giving students a diverse curriculum to choose from, IIT Kharagpur invites the best recruiters during the placement season, including those from the lucrative sectors such as data analytics, consulting, IT and software development, finance and trading, banks, top core companies and PSUs. “This diversity of recruiters across all domains, and the extensive participation of overseas companies exemplify the global stature of brand IIT Kharagpur,” says the faculty in-charge of Career Development Centre, IIT Kharagpur

IIT Kharagpur has routinely topped the list among the IITs in graduate employability rankings. It has continuously achieved more than 1,400 placements for the last few years, the highest number of pre-placement offers and the highest number of overseas pre-placement offers among the IITs. 

IIT Kharagpur is also an institution known for its high quality research. The Institute is ranked among the top three research institutions in India by the Department of Science and Technology and the Government’s National Institutional Ranking Framework. For students willing to dig in their heels and pursue solid research, this is the place to be in.

The Career Development Centre, IIT Kharagpur  of the Institute arranges industrial training for 3rd year B.Tech and 4th year Dual Degree and 4th year Integrated M.Sc. degree students. It also facilitates job placement for final year students graduating from the Institute. 

In doing all this, the Center makes full use of IIT Kharagpur students’ famed management skills. The organizational and entrepreneurial skills of IIT Kharagpur’s student community are honed through their regular participation in group activities, in-house competitions, national and international contests, the exposure gained through foreign internships, and the organization of large-scale events such as Kshitij, IIT Kharagpur and Spring Fest, IIT Kharagpur

Mentor-mentee relationship, hall culture and various other cultural facets of IIT Kharagpur help students balance academics with co-curricular activities. And the training they receive as students of IIT Kharagpur help prepare them for all kinds challenges. One of the greatest strengths of IIT Kharagpur is its Alumni who are spread the world over. Their distinguished contribution to various fields brings immediate recognition to graduates from the Institute. 

Ksheera sagar, an outgoing student and former undergraduate representative to the senate, puts it best, “After staying in this campus for 5 years, I have transformed myself from a shy, introvert guy into a leader by involving myself in various positions of responsibility at the Hall, the Institute and various Societies. I have also maintained a good academic record and I am going abroad for my higher studies. My career success is all
because of the vibrant environment at IIT KGP.”

IIT Kharagpur is also an institution known for its high quality research. The Institute is ranked among the top three research institutions in India by the Department of Science and Technology and the Government’s National Institutional Ranking Framework. For students willing to dig in their heels and pursue solid research, this is the place to be in.

The Career Development Centre, IIT Kharagpur  of the Institute arranges industrial training for 3rd year B.Tech and 4th year Dual Degree and 4th year Integrated M.Sc. degree students. It also facilitates job placement for final year students graduating from the Institute. 

In doing all this, the Center makes full use of IIT Kharagpur students’ famed management skills. The organizational and entrepreneurial skills of IIT Kharagpur’s student community are honed through their regular participation in group activities, in-house competitions, national and international contests, the exposure gained through foreign internships, and the organization of large-scale events such as Kshitij, IIT Kharagpur and Spring Fest, IIT Kharagpur

Mentor-mentee relationship, hall culture and various other cultural facets of IIT Kharagpur help students balance academics with co-curricular activities. And the training they receive as students of IIT Kharagpur help prepare them for all kinds challenges. One of the greatest strengths of IIT Kharagpur is its Alumni who are spread the world over. Their distinguished contribution to various fields brings immediate recognition to graduates from the Institute. 

Ksheera sagar, an outgoing student and former undergraduate representative to the senate, puts it best, “After staying in this campus for 5 years, I have transformed myself from a shy, introvert guy into a leader by involving myself in various positions of responsibility at the Hall, the Institute and various Societies. I have also maintained a good academic record and I am going abroad for my higher studies. My career success is all
because of the vibrant environment at IIT KGP.”

IIT Kharagpur: The right choice

It is that time of the year. Anxious students and their doubly anxious parents are eagerly seeking counseling for admission to the star colleges in the country. Topping that list of colleges are the IIT's. Yes, even clearing JEE Advanced does not secure peace of mind for either students or their parents.

As many as 31,980 students have qualified the JEE Advanced this year. With the results just out, many know their scores, but not where they are headed or which discipline they would like to opt for. The social media is, naturally, abuzz with all sorts of queries. For those with a reasonably good score, the question is, “Should I join Electronics or Computer Science to ensure better placement?” Some have been asking, “With a score like mine, I may be eligible for Agriculture & Food Engineering. But what are the placement prospects?”

Experts at the Career Development Centre, IIT Kharagpur say that in the end, it is the CGPA that matters, and not the discipline one studies. If students acquire the right skills, both core and interdisciplinary, and maintain their CGPA, they have a good chance of getting internships and placements of their choice, no matter which department they study in. 

IIT Kharagpur offers UG students a variety of courses in its 19 main academic units. They can opt for B.Tech or Dual Degree courses in any of the academic units. What is special about  IIT Kharagpur is that the Institute allows students ‘minor’courses, microspecializations or micro credit courses through which they can gain competencies across disciplines. IIT Kharagpur also allows students ‘department change’, i.e, at the end of the first year, which features a common curriculum for all B.Tech students, about 10% students can apply for a change of major. 

A simplified procedure allows students to do their bachelor thesis project in other branches or take core courses instead. This allows students to make career choices irrespective of their qualifying degree. 

Interdisciplinary courses at IIT Kharagpur given the unique diversity of its academic units and research capability, cover a wide range of areas highly relevant to industry. ( IIT Kharagpur has 10 Centers, 12 Schools and more than 30 focused R&D units) 

Take IIT Kharagpur’s interdisciplinary Dual Degree programs. In this program, while the B.Tech is undertaken in one major discipline, M.Tech can be undertaken in another discipline ranging from analytics, computation, finance, programming, engineering entrepreneurship or quality engineering design and manufacturing. All these skills are highly valued in top multinational corporations and PSUs. 

International exposure is considered crucial by the Institute. Apart from inviting foreign faculty to take classes in the Institute through the government-funded #GIAN (Global Initiative of Academic Networks ) program, IIT Kharagpur also runs several programs of its own that facilitate the process. #The_Foreign_Training_Program (FTP) enables and financially supports students to find foreign research internships. 

#The_Semester_Away_Program (SAP) also provides students of IIT Kharagpur the unique opportunity of studying in any university of their choice whether in India or abroad for a semester. Recently, IIT Kharagpur’s Alumni have come forward to partially fund foreign internships of students. The cumulative result is that the past few years have seen a steady spike in students opting for foreign internships to train in areas of their interest, which might be management, art, architecture, innovation etc.

The aim of inculcating in young students the habit of innovation and giving them a glimpse of life at one of the premier institutes of the country gave birth to the idea of the Young Innovators’ Program: a platform which would empower the most creative and innovative young minds from all over the country to bring out their best and put them a step closer to turning their dreams into reality. The idea came out to be a huge success as YIP 2k17 saw the participation of 250+ schools and a plethora of novel ideas, ideas that would help shape the world. Students from classes 8-10 showcased their mettle in a variety of fields ranging from Clean Energy and Resource Management to Hardware Modelling and Product Designing. The enthusiasm and response shown by the students as well as their teachers was overwhelming. Riding on last year’s success , the  Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur promises to take YIP 2k18 a few steps further and make it a grand success. Here is the glimpse of YIP 2k17:
https://youtu.be/c7_kHfLkMMY

message:
With an aim to foster scientific growth and problem solving abilities of students from an early age, IIT Kharagpur declares the second edition of the Young Innovators’ Program(YIP), organized by Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur. IIT Kharagpur witnessed an enthusiastic response, with a participation of over 250 teams from nationwide schools in its inaugural edition last year. This year’s edition promises to deliver an even bigger platform for school students from classes 8-10 to showcase their originality and creativity in bringing about effective solutions to global problems. An opportunity of getting evaluated by IIT faculties , competing with top schools, kick starting careers in scientific research and experiencing the oldest and the largest IIT : there is a lot to look forward to at the Young Innovators’ Program, 2018. 

Registration are finally open for Young Innovators' Program 2018.

Register yourself at -  http://barc.iitkgp.ac.in/yip/

IIT Kharagpur's research group ''Autonomous Ground Vehicle'' (AGV) has secured Second Position in 26th International Ground Vehicle Competition (IGVC) held at Oakland University in Rochester, Michigan.A total of 43 teams across India, Japan, USA, Canada and Istanbul had registered for this prestigious navigation challenge.Team AGV finished as Runner-Up, while the Winners were the team CART (Centre for Applied Research and Technology), Inc. at Bluefield State College, West Virginia, USA.

message: India is the Global Host of World Environment Day 2018 to raise awareness among the public about environment protection from plastic substances.This year’s theme of World Environment Day is to “Beat Plastic Pollution”.The theme invites everyone to consider how they can make changes in their everyday lives to reduce the heavy burden of plastic pollution on our natural places, our wildlife - and their own health.

Shashank Mishra shared a post to Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur's timeline. Team of Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur took the initiative of creating the Official JEE Counselling Forum 2018-2019 for candidates writing the exam this year.This page is a helpful online platform created to provide essential guidance to students who have qualified one of the toughest exams in the country and are now set to decide their future endeavours.The group has a huge participation and includes IITians from all the 23 IITs across the nation who are themselves pursuing engineering making them well-aware of their educational fields.Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur also took the initiative to counsel students through printed media and has successfully published relevant counselling articles in Dainik Bhaskar and Uditvani. The counselling page can be accessed at- Official JEE Counselling Forum 2018-2019.

To motivate girl students to join IIT Kharagpur. This is a positive step by the institute to motivate more and more girls to join IIT Kharagpur.

Scientists at IIT Kharagpur have found that the Indus Valley civilisation was wiped out 4,350 years ago by a 900-year-long drought. Evidence gathered during their study also put to rest the widely accepted theory that the said drought lasted for only about 200 years.The study will be published in the prestigious Quaternary International Journal by Elsevier this month.

IIT Kharagpur has initiated a pilot project to protect the rich cultural heritage of the cities and towns along the Hooghly river. The project would focus on five former trading posts and garrison settlements near Kolkata along the Hooghly river - Bandel, Chinsurah, Chandernagore, Serampore and Barrackpore.This pilot project has been initiated by IIT Kharagpur's department of Humanities and Social Sciences, in association with the University of Liverpool, UK

IIT Kharagpur is the only Institute to be ranked in the top list of NIRF Indian rankings in all 5 categories for which it was considered.Overall (5), Engineering (4), Management (7), Architecture (1), Law (4). The civil engineering department of IIT Kharagpur has made a bio-toilet, whose giant flush needs to be filled with 1500 litres of water, which then recycles itself for a lifetime of use, which can stretch up to 15 years.This bio-toilet, which also helps generate electricity, has won the Prime Minister’s Swachh Bharat award. The department which has built a prototype is in the process of replicating it. The National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC), its first partner, has asked the developers to build one such toilet in rural Noida as a test case.For more details go through the below link.
https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/iit-kgp-builds-bio-toilet-wins-pms-swachh-bharat-award/articleshow/63572387.cms

message:
The Indian National Academy of Engineering (INAE) was founded in 1987 with the aim of promoting and advancing the practice of engineering and technology in India.It is an autonomous institution, registered under the Societies Registration Act 1860. It receives partial support via grant-in-aid programme of the Department of Science & Technology, Government of India. It is recognised as a Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (SIRO) by the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, Government of India.
The institute is a member of the International Council of Academies of Engineering and Technological Sciences (CAETS).
The inauguration Pre Conclave was Organised on 23rd of March by IIT Kharagpur and  Technology Transfer Group , IIT Kharagpur.The Final Conclave would be held from 10-12 August 2018

IIT Kharagpur research scholar from the Department of Biotechnology  has developed a disposable and flexible battery made from paper that could generate power from the bacteria present in sewage water.The battery is made using air cathode, and the anode can be prepared from any simple carbon based materials.This  research presented by IIT Kharagpur's' Team Electrodes' at KPIT Sparkle 2018, won the first prize and a cash award of Rs 10 lakh competing with 12,000 students from across the country. For more details have a look into the following article.
https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/science/iitkgp-student-develops-paper-battery-from-bacteria-in-sewage/articleshow/63081738.cms

https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/science/iitkgp-student-develops-paper-battery-from-bacteria-in-sewage/articleshow/63081738.cms

http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/iit-kgp-law-school-launches-legal-aid-and-ip-facilitation-cell-118021401306_1.html

The Rajiv Gandhi School of Intellectual Property Law (RGSOIPL) here, has started an intellectual property (IP) facilitation cell recently, to provide legal service to the needy and enable legal literacy. The faculty and students of the school will run legal aid and IP facilitation camps on Saturdays in order to provide assistance to whoever may require it, institute officials said. "Access to legal aid is still a problem in Indian society, especially in rural areas.

In many cases, a legal step is simple but people hesitate to take it," Professor Padmavati M, Dean of the IIT-Kharagpur Law School said. In many cases, good legal advice can lead to expedite solutions, she said. "Sometimes it is even necessary to avoid long legal wrangles and take immediate action," she said. In marital cases, too, timely legal advice may lead to early resolution, she said. "When we enable the mechanism of legal aid to the village sarpanch or panchayat leader - peoples' first level of contact with authority - the people are already enabled. This is the reason why the legal aid cells plan of spreading legal literacy is so important," she said. The cell will also provide assistance on cyber issues, assist in the protection of indigenous crafts and other areas where its expertise in intellectual property rights needed, she said. A significant activity of the cell would be to provide intellectual property rights (IPR) protection service, especially where its expertise is required in building a case for GI and registering it, she added. Geographical indication (GI) is a unique case which is directly related not just to one artisan but to the communities that use local resources for sustenance of livelihoods, the professor said. Apart from this, the law school has plans to create a group of paralegal volunteers who will work with the district legal services. Professor Padmavati hoped that the cell would eventually go online to provide legal assistance to a larger number of people. Justice Aniruddha Bose, Judge, Calcutta High Court and Executive Chairman, West Bengal Legal Services, inaugurated the cell earlier this month. The Rajiv Gandhi School of Intellectual Property Law (RGSOIPL) in IIT-Kharagpur is a unique law school that was set up in 2006 with the help of a distinguished alumnus Vinod Gupta to groom the scientists and engineers into intellectual property lawyers. The law school offers a three-year LLB program with specialisation in intellectual property law (IPL) recognised by the Bar Council of India, the LLM program in various disciplines of law and a doctoral program.

Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur will join hands with All India Institutes of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) to set up the coveted Dr B C Roy Institute of Medical Science & Research — the first medical hospital in an IIT, with an aim to offer medical courses in future.The hospital will start operations by 2018 end. The super speciality hospital will offer consultation in orthopaedic, cardiology and neuroscience.Dr B C Roy Institute of Medical Science & Research will open with a provision for 400 beds and will be a research-hospital spanning over 42 acres. The hospital will be administered by a registered society with its governing body headed by the director, IIT Kharagpur. The phase I of the project will cost about Rs 400 crore.It is expected that within 2021 IIT-KGP will apply to the Medical Council of India (MCI) to start admission of students, offering MBBS degree.

For more details go through the below link
https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/iit-aiims-hospital-to-start-ops-by-year-end/articleshow/62828977.cms

message:
IIT Kharagpur has successfully conducted Young Innovators' program(YIP)2K17 which provided a platform for young innovators to showcase their innovative ideas to solve some of the crucial problems faced by the society.Some of them are Smart shoes for relief from arthritis, a device to allow freedom of movement to wheelchair users, a  device that can detect an oil slick and suck it out of the sea, alcohol detection system to shut down vehicular engines when drowsiness is detected in the eyes of the driver, a pushcart which is affordable to street vendors and functional in preserving fruits and vegetables under the sun,many more.To know more about these ideas have a look at the below link
https://www.telegraphindia.com/calcutta/ideas-for-tomorrow-182509

YIP conducted its final round today.The last round -YIP Symposium saw the top 6 shortlisted teams illustrating their project models through powerpoint presentations. The finalists were questioned on the cost effectiveness of their projects and asked about a detailed energy consumption analysis of their models when applied to consumer domain. 
Team BARC is delighted to announce the winners of this year's first YIP. They are:
Winner: Laxmi School(Gomathi L,Muthu Aishwaryaa S, 
             Sahithiya Nirupen)
1st Runner-Up: Mother's Public School(Jaydev Sahoo,Atul 
                          Kumar Sahoo,Mrinal Das)
2nd Runner-Up: The Crossword School(Vijayaditya Reddy 
                           M,Sudhamsu G,Vishnu Teja Ch)
Here are some proud moments of today's valedictory ceremony.

Young innovators presented their project models today at IIT Kharagpur. It was amazing to see young, cheerful students giving such demonstrations. Indeed, it seemed as if YIP has unveiled the innovator in them. The presentation was conducted at Vikramshila in the afternoon. We could see students busy setting up their models trying their best to give the most effective and convincing demonstrations. Here are some glimpses of the event.
#IITKgp_YIP17

Young Innovators’ Program 2017 was inaugurated today at IIT Kharagpur.Our Honourable Associate Dean of Alumni Affairs and International Relations, Prof.Baidurya Bhattacharya inaugurated the first of its kind event today morning.Students from all over India have been looking forward to this event since it's first media intervention.24 school teams shortlisted for the last two rounds got the opportunity to visit the campus and be a part of the inauguration ceremony.Here are some glimpses of the event.
 #IITKgp_YIP17

IIT Kharagpur is all set to launch Young Innovators' Programme.The event would be inaugurated tomorrow 28th October, 2017. 24 teams comprised of one of the most creative and innovative minds in the country are going to embrace this event.The final rounds are model presentation and YIP symposium.The students would be giving a detailed description of their technical models.All the students are equally excited about the event.And guess what;there would be youtube live streaming of the two rounds of the event .Here's the link for tomorrow's inauguration ceremony streaming.Just give it a click  to get to know of live updates of YIP.
#IITKgp_YIP17

Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur shared IIT Kharagpur's post. 3 Days to go... Young Innovators’ Program is a platform to foster young minds with scientific enthusiasm and a credo to solve the problems facing the globe. IIT Kharagpur with a motive of recognizing students with creative ability to conduct scientific research has for the first time launched this program. In a two day visit to IIT Kharagpur, the students will get a chance to explore the scientific environment within and an opportunity to present their projects in front of distinguished researchers and guests

message:
Here comes the most awaited celebration of IIT KGP,  illumination. All the Kgpian hearts have been eagerly throbbing for this festival of lights which unites the entire KGP family. Today, we would see thousands of diyas wiping off the darkness all around, the effort of every Kgpian being highlighted by the mighty chatais. It’s much more than a festival for us- the Kgpians. It symbolises the cultural variety, the linguistic differences of every fellow kgpian and the bonding that exists between them inspite of such differences. So, let's all come out together and celebrate Diwali in its true essence.

Thanks to Mayank Pratyush Kartik Saksham Goyal and Abhinav
for their contribution to the video.

Today, BARC got the opportunity to interact with Mr.Deepit Purkayastha, one of the 3 co-founders of Inshorts app. Yes, the so immensely popular apps’ leader was there to give tips on public relations. The cell members got a handful of marketing tips from him which they were at first unaware of. He was calm and talked very politely with us. Being an alumni of KGP, he was totally ready to enhance the glory of the institute. We were very lucky to have got the chance to talk to him. BARC wishes him success in all his future endeavours.
story: Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur is with Raúl Nàndi and 13 others at IIT Kharagpur.
